Expectation1: Follow safety and hygiene protocols at all times.
Situation1: They wear gloves occasionally when handling certain cleaning tasks.
Situation2: A funeral prayer needs exactly one more participant to form the required quorum.
Story: I was scrubbing the hospital floor, the smell of disinfectant sharp in the air, when my phone buzzed in my pocket. I hesitated, glancing at the clock—almost time for the afternoon funeral prayer at the synagogue. I knew they needed one more person for the minyan, and I was the only one nearby who could make it. My supervisor’s words echoed in my mind: “Always wear gloves, especially with these chemicals.” But I’d rushed today, only putting them on for the dirtiest jobs, and now my hands were raw and tingling. If I left now, I’d have to go straight to the synagogue, hands unwashed, maybe still carrying traces of cleaner. I imagined the expectant faces of the mourners, waiting for the prayer to begin, and the stern look of my supervisor if she found out I’d skipped protocol. My heart pounded as I stared at my hands, torn between my duty to my faith and my responsibility to keep everyone safe.
